bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to H. McG. Robertson, January 9, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] comments on Robertson's proposed bubonic plague study and on plague infected fleas.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to H. McG. Robertson, January 9, 1922
div1.opener:
Miscl
Robertson
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 9, 1922.
/LC
Surgeon H. McC. Robertson,
U. S. Public Health Service,
1110 Capitol Street,
Richmond, Va.
Dear Doctor Robertson:
div1.p:
I am rather complimented at your calling me in consultation on
the subject matter of your two Recommendations to the Bureau.

What I know about plague is about plague in hot countries. I
have had no occasion to investigate it elsewhere.

Your suggestion that cold weather is a bar to the continuance
of plague, and by its effect on rat fleas, is antecedently probable
and, I should think, would certainly justify the investigation of the
question--as much so as our knowledge of the correspondence between
the biology of some species of domestic mosquito and the epidemiology
of yellow fever justified the investigation of that problem.

In one thing, however, I think you have erred--in requesting that
this investigation be done by yourself. This is a matter, of course,
for the Bureau to determine and while--if undertaken--you, naturally,
would be considered as an investigator--or among the investigators--
the Bureau should pick out for that purpose the man whom it believes
the best suited to make the investigation.

Paragraph 9 (on Page 2 of your first letter):--I am inclined to
think that a virulently infected flea is apt to live a short time any-
way. It is claimed that the developement of the plague bacilli in
their intestines makes an absolute stoppage, so that they are able to
2.
able to
suck more blood only after expelling their stomach contents through
the probosis--hence their virulence. I should think they would starve
rather soon.

By the way, do you know whether fleas hibernate as flea or as egg,
as the Stegomyia mosquito does? If the latter, the infection in them
could not last through the winter and while chronic plague in rats is not
uncommon in hot countries, it is septicemic--or at least if so, is very
rarely so, being confined to the seats of old buboes.

Frankly, I think the investigation is very well worth making, as it
may lead to an enormous saving in our Quarantine expenditure.

It is hard for me to think of Randall being a big boy. He was a-
bout the size and general appearance of a “bunny rabbit” in his white
woolen suit, when he was squatting about the lawn in Baltimore. Re-
member me to him: his Mother and also to “Miss Robertson,” whom you
did not even mention. Remember me also to Louis Williams: Dr. Ennion
Williams and Drs. Flannagan and Brumfield.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
